Next: let‚Äôs compare and contrast the end user experience of fetching authenticated data between Gatsby and a server-rendered application.

plugin, we enable a fully-featured, progressive web application that works offline and creates an app shell by registering a service worker. An app shell is essentially separate components of your application (e.g. header, footer, sidebar, etc.) that are instantly available from a service worker while dynamic content is fetched in the background. This creates a great end-user experience, as the application is able to visually populate instantly as data loads into place in the background.
If we consider this approach, the technique looks like the following:
Render as much content, as possible, up front (e.g. the app shell)
Make async data requests to load disparate pieces, e.g. load page content from an API, particularly an API with authentication

Let‚Äôs compare this approach with the server-rendered approach. Consider an authenticated API call for this example. This API call is used to populate page data before it‚Äôs sent (as HTML) to the end user. We‚Äôre forced to defer loading for the entire page and the bottleneck of the API response, rather than serving the app shell as dynamic data loads in the background.

frontmatter.title: Gatsby for Apps
frontmatter.excerpt: Gatsby is great for not only static sites but also traditional web applications. Using Gatsby enables the benefits of both static and web applications so you don't have to sacrifice the advantages of one approach to reap the benefits of the other.
